instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.P3V42_G3H: What is P3V42_G3H? P3V42_G3H is a typo of PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message:
Hi I have a dim green light and didn?t find p3v42 at L6990
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
2 <SIGNAL>P3V42_FB</SIGNAL> =3.7v
3 <SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_TON</SIGNAL> = 15v
4 <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> =16.5v
6 <SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_SW</SIGNAL> =0v
7 <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> =16.5v
8 <SIGNAL>P3V42_FB</SIGNAL> =3.7v
9 <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> =0v
10 <SIGNAL>P3V42_REF3</SIGNAL>=0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message:
Post first diode mode to ground at L6995.
If OK, check/replace <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>/95.
If still the same, change <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message:
Diode mode .003
i removed <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C6995</CAPACITOR>
i have the same .003v on pin 2 of l6990
I see in the schematic that it goes to all the board so it?s either smc or this chip <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> I?m hoping it?s the chip but my gut feeling is the smc I will pull the chip and report back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message:
I mentioned that caps if OK value at 3V42 line.
Why did you touch them, if short???

Enough low value, so easy to find the culprit injecting voltage.
Start with 1V, no more than 3.8V max...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message: Ok I found a issue :/ <CAPACITOR>C5750</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> I powered it up and got 12.57 :( the mux got hot and it?s no fan spin. How Important is this smc manual reset chip or can I continue to diagnose till it arrives.

threads.message: Oh and steady green light on charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message: So it?s no short on <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> it?s on pin 2 so I?m glad that  the smc is probably ok <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> on pin 1 is .003v so it?s either the chip or <CAPACITOR>C5020</CAPACITOR> I don?t like heating near mux what?s you opinion on removing this cap and or <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message:
Both U/<CAPACITOR>C5750</CAPACITOR> shorted?

<CHIP>U5750</CHIP>(55  are only used to do manual SMC reset with keyboard.
You get same thing removing charger and battery.
Of course, no need to remove battery, doing SMC reset from keyboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message: Not both one of them I?m guessing is shorted

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message: Honestly i removed <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> and the pin that goes to <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>, <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>,<CAPACITOR>C5020</CAPACITOR> is .003v to ground. As I?m reading the schematic I believe it?s either <CHIP>U5019</CHIP> or <CAPACITOR>C5020</CAPACITOR> I was wondering about heating up near mux since it has underfil how easy is it to mess the the mux up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message:
Use alcohol method and you should be able to locate individual component which fails.
Videos available on Internet; Louis had something on the channel I think...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light missing p3v42
threads.message: Honestly because when I use the power supply the same part <CAPACITOR>C5750</CAPACITOR> overheats. I change it with the same if I remove <CAPACITOR>C5750</CAPACITOR> and power it up the mux gets hot
